that and dont worry about the xantham gum since that acts as the binding

bread usually dont taste all that good.

top_comment.text:
Please don't heat up plastic wrap, when it's directly touching the food. 
Since not all plastic wrap is produced the same way, it can contain 
chemicals that you don't want to eat. Use parchment paper instead, that's 
what it's made for.

Also, you don't have to scoop out the flesh. The hokkaido skin is eatable, 
and after being cooked in the oven, it's soft enough to blend. So save 
yourself some time =)﻿
top_comment.author: ThisIsMyFullName

comments.text: He said "be sure to use bake safe cling film"
comments.author: Chloe Wild

comments.text: +San Don Besoffskic Na, welches Wort meinst du? :)
comments.author: G Knucklez

comments.text:
Well, I can personally really feel a difference when making soup or purée 
when I leave the skin on, even though I blend and sift it.
The difference is hard to explain, in my native language we have a word for 
it, which sadly doesn't translate into English, so I really can't find the 
right word.
But, if it doesn't make a difference to you, it's great!
And yeah, you are right about the waste, but my dog highly appreciates the 
peels. :D
comments.author: San Don Besoffskic

comments.text:
+San Don Besoffskic You can not sense the texture of the skin, once you 
cook and blend it. Even without blending it, the skin will be so soft, it's 
hard to sense it in your mouth. But the skin does make the finished mixture 
darker, instead of bright orange, so that's a good reason not to put it in. 
Personally, I prefer the "natural" look, with the skin in. Plus, it saves 
time and food waste =)
comments.author: ThisIsMyFullName

comments.text:
I agree with you one the plastic wrap, but I do also always remove the skin 
from hokkaido pumpkins, it just has a better texture and look in my 
opinion. :)
But of course it is edible and up for personal preference.
comments.author: San Don Besoffskic

comments.text: I'd use baking paper instead of plastic wrap, too!
comments.author: AnnK H

top_comment.text:
all this gluten phobia is pure nonsense.. you remove natural binding and 
add some synthetic gum. SOLVED :D﻿
top_comment.author: churchmanas

comments.text:
+Jasmine Imren your mum didn't become celiac by eating too much gluten. 
this is nonsense. all Italians should be celiacs then... we eat pasta and 
pizza or bread almost once a day every day of the year. Celiac disease is a 
genetic disease and it's very serious.
comments.author: gplzan

comments.text:
Actually my mum became allergic to gluten because she lived in Rome for a 
few years so she ate too much gluten but probably if she ate a bit less 
then she could still eat it now so it's good to choose gluten free things 
if you can:)

top_comment.text: How did you take the pie out of the dish??? O.o﻿
top_comment.author: Leon M

comments.text: My pleasure. They are great things to have in the kitchen! :D
comments.author: valhalla83

comments.text: Oh cool, had no idea, thanks!
comments.author: Leon M

comments.text:
Those kinds of pie/flan pans/tins have a base that drops in to the ring 
part of it (ie. there is two parts to the tin). Once it's cooked and the 
tin is cool enough to touch (about 2-5 minutes after taking it out of the 
oven), you stand the base of the tin on something tall an narrow (I often 
use an up-turned coffee mug) and the side drops away, leaving the pie on 
the base. You can then simply slide the pie off the base on to your serving 
plate using a spatula if needed.


Picture - 
http://www.judgecookware.co.uk/images/sites/judge/ranges/judge-bakeware/products/flan-tin.jpg
comments.author: valhalla83

top_comment.text:
Jon, or Jamie, what type of gluten free flour did you use? In North America 
I can get several different brands that have different mixes of tapioca 
starch, rice flour, and potato starch. Do you know what kind of mix the 
flour you used was?﻿
top_comment.author: Matthew Corbett

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: Matthew Corbett

comments.text:
It's a blended Gluten Free White Flour from Doves Farm. Rice, Potato, 
Tapioca, Maize & Buckwheat.
comments.author: Jamie Oliver

comments.text:
+valhalla83  on top of that, for anyone that uses a the premixed blends, 
before adding the xantham gum, check to see if the blend already has it in 
there. If it already does, you dont need to add any extra I believe.
comments.author: KajTaotsu

comments.text:
Any should do. Premixed 'gluten free white baking flour' is often good 
enough, and usually contain a standard mixture of those flours and starches 
you mentioned.

I have some friends that are gluten and dairy free, is there a version of 
this that is also dairy free too?﻿
top_comment.author: Zeues777

comments.text:
We don't have a dairy-free version but feel free to experiment with the 
recipe. Apple sauce can work really well as a substitute for eggs in 
baking. For lots of awesome dairy-free recipes check out these recipes 
http://www.jamieoliver.com/recipes/category/special-diets/dairy-free/

captions.text: Gluten Free Pumpkin Pie
Hey FoodTubers

I'm John, I'm the head chef of 15 London
I'm here with this amazing gluten free
pumpkin pie recipe
beautifully soft, silky filling, wrapped in a crisp and crumbly pastry

it's perfect for Thanksgiving but it's also
amazing if you want to use it all year round
Okay so let's start with the pumpkin. First of all we'll just take the little top off
like so, cut the pumpkin
use a spoon and just scoop it out
Right perfect we've taken out the seeds now let's cut that squash
So all we're going to do is just cut it into nice little quarters
pop iit in the tray
cover this in foil now, pop it in the oven
180 celsius for about an hour
or just check it and just give it a little prick and see if it's giving
Right so my pumpkins are in the oven roasting. Now I'm going to make the pastry

this is the most important bit, add 250
grams a gluten-free white flour
into the bowl  and what we're going to do is some xantham gum
You want to add half a teaspoon of this into your flour
This replaces the job of the gluten and stops the pastry from crumbling
50 grams of sugar, 125 grams of butter

and a little pinch of cinnamon as well. Mix
all this together like a crumble mixture.

Make sure all the butter is completely
mixed into the flour.

So that's got a nice little crumbling texture,
if you can see there
it's nicely broken up, no real lumps in there
Make a little well, pour in your milk, in goes a whole egg
bring it into the middle, so really just sort of kneed it back together
roll it around inside the bowl, create a nice little ball
Here we go, pat it down, wrap it in some cling film, and what you want to do is pop it in the fridge

for about half an hour, just to let it
rest
Right so don't be afraid this pastry's gonna be quite hard because it has been in the
fridge for half an hour
it's quite firm. Just roll it in between some cling film
what this will do, it will stop it from sticking, pop your pastry in the middle

So give it a little beat this will take a
little bit of work
but give it time it will come together
Do it about five mm
using your tart case, flip it over, push it in all the corners
Right once you're comfortable with it, remove the cling film
Don't worry if you've gone over a little bit
push it on the sides, take a knife trim it up nicely
Save this pastry, you'll need it to decorate the top of the pie
Take a fork and then just it all down the middle
Pricking the base stops the pastry from rising, and keeps the bottom of the pie nice and flat

Right rest it in the fridge for another 10
minutes just let it cool down a little
bit and set up again
So my pumpkin's ready now
Okay so the pumpkin's been in for an hour, let it cool then we'll scoop it out
Right meanwhile while that's cooling what we want to do is blind bake the pastry
Take some cling film, something like rice
any sort of grain will do, fill it right up to the top
And what we're doing, the reason why we blind bake it, is basically it stops it rising up too much

Bake this for 10 to 12 minutes with the
rice on
Then we'll remove the rice bag and bake it for another five minutes
Just until it comes nice and golden
Okay so this is ready, what we're gunna do is leave this to cool for five to ten minutes

that gives me time to get on with the
filling, in here we've got the pumpkins

make sure they're nice and tender and
all we've done is just scoop out the flesh
There we go, right now to the rest of it

So what we've got is fifty grams of golden brown butter, 
brown butter is simply butter which has
been cooked on a low heat
until golden brown, you get this almost salted caramel flavor
Blitz it up, so it's nice and smooth
Right for the rest of the filling we add 125 grams of sugar
we have a pinch of cinnamon
2 teaspoons of vanilla extract
4 tablespoons of gluten-free flour, quarter of a teaspoon of nutmeg
And now two eggs and what we want to do is just whisk them up a little bit before we add it to the bowl
Place that all in the bowl and give it one last blitz
Right so all my ingredients are mixed together now I'm going to fill the pastry case
take your pumpkin pour it into the middle
Make sure you spread it out all evenly
covering all the edges, there we go, remember all the trim I had?
I made some beautiful little lattice
And what we're going to do is lay it over the top the pumpkin pie to make it look pretty

and then again to make it a classical
pumpkin pie we go across
So next thing we're going to do before we put it back in the oven, we're going to egg wash it
bake it in the oven 180
45 to 50 minutes
It's just come out the oven, it's nice and golden on the outside

lovely little shine on top and now to
finish it off we're just going to give it

little dusting of icing sugar and
cinnamon
Little pinch of cinnamon
My mouth is watering already, there we go,  look at that, looking beautiful
Got that lovely little brown butter going all the way through it pumpkins nice and golden
We're ready to taste it
absolutely delicious
you can taste the vanilla, the cinnamon, and that delicious brown butter coming through
it's so so good, guys you've got to try it, head over to drinkstube they've got this amazing

vegan pumpkin pie smoothie check that
out also for this

and loads more gluten-free specialty diets
head over to JamieOliver.com

and don't forget to like,subscribe and
share
It's free.

title: Gluten Free Pumpkin Pie | Thanksgiving Recipe | Jon Rotherham
